population_specificity: Zebrafish (Danio rerio) subjected to prolonged chronic unpredictable stress (PCUS).
interactions: Combined with fluoxetine and LPS, but specific interaction effects were not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) modulates leukocyte function and the development of systemic lupus erythematosus in mouse models.
results_summary: Dietary EPA supplementation improved lupus manifestations, including reduced autoantibody production and immunocomplex deposition in kidneys. EPA also remodeled B cell membrane lipid composition and fluidity, preventing differentiation into autoantibody-producing plasma cells.
population_specificity: Drug-induced and spontaneous lupus mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between the EPA/AA ratio and long-term cardiovascular events in patients with coronary artery disease.
results_summary: A low EPA/AA ratio was associated with significantly higher rates of adverse cardiovascular events, including cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, and ischemic stroke, compared to a high EPA/AA ratio. The study found that patients with lower EPA/AA ratios had worse outcomes over the follow-up period.
population_specificity: Japanese patients with coronary artery disease who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) on T-helper type 1 (Th1) cell responses and identify associated pathways.
results_summary: EPA reduced Th1 cell differentiation and IFN-γ secretion, lowered MHC II expression on dendritic cells, and inhibited TNF-α secretion in a DC-independent model. It regulated pathways related to inflammation, immunity, and metabolism, with effects comparable to DHA but distinct in specific cytokine modulation.
population_specificity: Naïve CD4+ T cells co-cultured with bone marrow-derived dendritic cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether changes in the EPA/AA ratio were associated with cardiovascular event rates in ACS patients receiving lipid-lowering therapy excluding PUFAs.
results_summary: A greater increase in the EPA/AA ratio was significantly associated with lower cardiovascular event rates (6.0% vs. 11.0%) over 3 years, indicating a protective effect. The results remained significant after adjusting for patient factors.
population_specificity: Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) patients not receiving polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs).
study_duration: 3 months (measurement of EPA/AA ratio change), with 3-year follow-up for outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of HPS/FGL1 in KRAS-mutated PDAC cells under EPA treatment and whether EPA could inhibit lipogenesis and cell survival in these cancer cells.
results_summary: EPA treatment reduced de novo lipogenic protein ACC-1, decreased p-STAT3 and HPS/FGL1 expressions, and suppressed cell viability in KRAS-mutated PDAC cells. HPS/FGL1 knockdown increased omega-3 PUFAs and EPA production, further inhibiting cancer cell growth.
population_specificity: KRAS-mutated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) cell lines (PANC-1, MIA PaCa-2, SUIT-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of leucoselect phytosome (containing EPA) on serum lipid metabolomics profiles and its potential chemopreventive effects in heavy smokers.
results_summary: Leucoselect phytosome significantly increased EPA and DHA levels, elevated unsaturated phosphatidylcholines, and raised anti-inflammatory PGE3, correlating with reduced bronchial cell proliferation. Posttreatment plasma also inhibited lung cancer cell line proliferation.
population_specificity: Heavy active and former smokers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) reverses palmitic acid (PA)-induced hepatic insulin resistance (IR) and to explore its underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: EPA reversed PA-induced IR in HepG2 cells, primarily by restoring mitochondrial protein function related to oxidative phosphorylation and the TCA cycle. It also alleviated PA-induced abnormalities in ATP production, ROS generation, and calcium content, with ROS/JUN identified as a common pathway in FFA-regulated IR.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (a human liver cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of Eicosapentaenoic Acid through prospective and retrospective case-control studies.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding Eicosapentaenoic Acid's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of MAG-EPA supplementation versus placebo on depression levels and other psychological symptoms in prostate cancer patients post-radical prostatectomy.
results_summary: The study found that several psychological symptoms decreased over time, but MAG-EPA did not produce greater reductions than the placebo. Omega-3 supplementation did not improve psychological symptoms in men treated with radical prostatectomy.
population_specificity: Men treated with radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of omega-3 supplementation, including eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), on fatty acid distribution, blood lipid profiles, inflammation, and disease activity in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplementation increased EPA and DHA levels, reduced the omega-6:omega-3 ratio, decreased triglycerides, and improved tender joint count in RA patients, though effects on ESR, CRP, and DAS28 were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients (1018 participants across 18 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of fatty acid supplementation, including eicosapentaenoic acid, on preventing and treating sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found that fatty acids, including eicosapentaenoic acid, showed positive effects in some clinical and pre-clinical studies, particularly when combined with exercise, but results were inconsistent across studies. Animal and cell studies suggested potential mechanisms like improved regenerative capacity and reduced oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (clinical studies) and animal/cell models (pre-clinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the conversion of ALA to EPA and the potential cardiovascular and anti-inflammatory benefits of ALA and its oxylipins.
results_summary: The study found that ALA supplementation is associated with improved lipid profiles, reduced inflammatory biomarkers like CRP, and lower cardiovascular disease risk, though the exact mechanisms (whether due to ALA, its oxylipins, or other factors) remain unclear.
population_specificity: Humans and mouse/cell models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) may contribute to cardiovascular benefits, particularly through its role in resolving inflammation via the EPA-RvE1-ChemR23 axis.
results_summary: The study found that EPA has dose-dependent cardiovascular benefits, potentially mediated through triglyceride lowering and anti-inflammatory mechanisms, including the production of resolvin E1 (RvE1). Genetic variations in the EPA-RvE1-ChemR23 axis may influence individual responses to EPA supplementation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cardiovascular prevention context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of long-chain omega-3 fatty acid (LCn3) supplementation on prostate cancer-specific quality of life in men treated by radical prostatectomy.
results_summary: Intention-to-treat analyses showed no significant difference between the fish oil and placebo groups, but per-protocol analyses at 12-month follow-up indicated a significantly greater improvement in urinary irritation function scores in the fish oil group.
population_specificity: 130 men treated by radical prostatectomy.
study_duration: Starting 7 weeks before surgery and continuing up to one-year post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Eicosapentaenoic Acid (EPA) on cancer cell proliferation and death, as well as its interaction with chemotherapy drugs in vitro.
results_summary: EPA did not induce proliferation in neuroblastoma, leukemia, lymphoma, or adult cancer cell lines and did not interfere with the cytotoxic effects of chemotherapy drugs. It caused minor fibroblast proliferation but did not protect them from cisplatin toxicity.
population_specificity: In vitro cancer cell lines (neuroblastoma, leukemia, lymphoma, pancreatic, colon, prostate) and fibroblasts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) supplements, alone or combined with docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), in improving cognitive function in elderly individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found that EPA and/or DHA supplements improved global cognition compared to placebo, with no significant effects on language fluency, executive functions, or depression. The supplements may also reduce blood amyloid-β-related biomarkers and inflammatory factors, though more research is needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the dose and duration of omega-3 supplementation required to achieve therapeutic blood levels of eicosapentaenoic acid (≥150 µg/mL or omega-3 index ≥8%) in people with chronic atherosclerotic disease.
results_summary: Supplementation at 1.8 g to 3.4 g per day for 3-6 months, or 4.4 g and above for 1-6 months, effectively increased blood omega-3 levels to therapeutic ranges in atherosclerotic patients. The study suggests routine omega-3 supplementation and higher dietary recommendations could improve clinical outcomes and reduce cardiac mortality risk.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic atherosclerotic disease
effective_dosage: 1.8 g to 3.4 g per day; 4.4 g and above per day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate alternative plant sources of essential fatty acids, focusing on long-chain omega-3 PUFAs like Eicosapentaenoic Acid, to address global nutritional demands sustainably.
results_summary: The study identified promising non-animal sources of omega-3 PUFAs, including algae, microorganisms, and GM plants, but noted that costs, acceptance, and formulation require further investigation.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of interventional studies with human data)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cardiovascular outcomes of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation (specifically EPA and EPA+DHA) against various placebo oils and standard care controls.
results_summary: EPA supplementation significantly reduced cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, and stroke compared to mineral oil placebo but showed no benefit over other placebo oils or controls. EPA also lowered coronary revascularization rates more than other oils but not compared to controls, while EPA+DHA reduced cardiovascular death risk compared to controls.
population_specificity: 141,009 patients from 17 RCTs, including those receiving EPA, EPA+DHA, or various placebo oils (mineral, corn, olive) or standard care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perinatal supplementation with n-3 LC-PUFA (including Eicosapentaenoic Acid) reduces the risk of asthma/wheeze and allergic asthma in offspring.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant overall reduction in asthma/wheeze risk (RR 0.93) or allergic asthma (RR 0.66), but subgroup analyses showed reduced risk in Europe, with doses ≥1200 mg/day, and when supplementation continued into lactation. A linear dose-response indicated a 2% risk reduction per 100 mg increase in daily n-3 LC-PUFA intake.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their offspring (3037 mother-infant pairs from eight RCTs).
effective_dosage: Daily supplementary dose of at least 1200 mg n-3 LC-PUFA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of n-3-PUFA supplementation on plasma lipoprotein subfractions in healthy older adults without cardiovascular disease or hypertriglyceridemia.
results_summary: n-3 PUFAs reduced large LDL particles by 17-18%, increased small dense LDL particles by 26-44%, increased cholesterol in large HDL particles by 32%, and decreased cholesterol in small HDL particles by 23%, while also reducing total triglycerides and systolic blood pressure. The study suggests potential benefits to lipoprotein profiles in healthy older adults.
population_specificity: Healthy older men and women (65-85 years old) without cardiovascular disease or hypertriglyceridemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of omega-3 PUFA supplements, particularly eicosapentaenoic acid, on outcomes in patients with lower extremity arterial disease (LEAD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that omega-3 PUFAs were not significantly associated with primary outcomes like ankle-brachial index or walking distance but were significantly associated with reduced triglyceride levels, with the effect size depending on eicosapentaenoic acid dosage.
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity arterial disease (LEAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardiovascular outcomes associated with omega-3 supplements, including eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), across different dosages.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplements showed no significant reduction in all-cause mortality, cardiac death, myocardial infarction, or stroke, except for a reduction in cardiac mortality at the equivalent dose of 2 capsules/day. Higher doses and specific formulations like icosapent ethyl ester warrant further investigation.
population_specificity: 97,709 participants from 19 randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if omega-3 PUFA intake, particularly EPA, prevents post-partum depression and whether IL-6 plays a role in this effect.
results_summary: Lower dietary omega-3 intake correlated with reduced EPA levels and higher post-partum depression risk, but IL-6's role in depression was unclear. Higher AA/EPA ratios in the second trimester were associated with higher depression scores.
population_specificity: 80 singleton pregnant women
study_duration: First and second trimesters, and post-partum

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate inter-individual variability in plasma TAG reduction following supplementation with long-chain n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids, specifically Eicosapentaenoic Acid, using lipidomic analysis.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with 3 g/day of long-chain n-3 fatty acids reduced plasma TAG concentrations in some participants, but about 30% did not respond. Lipidomic analysis identified distinct responder phenotypes, suggesting variability in metabolic response.
population_specificity: 130 participants (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
effective_dosage: 3 g/day of long-chain n-3 fatty acids (in fish oil capsules).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of an EPA-enriched oral supplement combined with gemcitabine in patients with advanced pancreatic cancer.
results_summary: The EPA group showed a 1-year survival probability of 35% compared to 19% in the gemcitabine group, with median survival times of 8.2 and 9.7 months, respectively. The hazard ratio for the EPA group was 0.79, suggesting a potential benefit.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced pancreatic cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence from RCTs on the efficacy of adding omega-3 supplementation to continuous sertraline therapy in adults with depression.
results_summary: The pooled standardized mean difference (SMD) for the Beck Depression Inventory was 0.50 (95% CI: -0.51, 1.50), indicating mixed results with no statistically significant effect. The meta-analysis included four RCTs with follow-up periods ranging from 8 to 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Adults with depression receiving sertraline therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether icosapent ethyl (IPE), a purified form of eicosapentaenoic acid, could maintain gynoid fat and bone mineral content in patients with metabolic syndrome over a 9-month period.
results_summary: The study found that IPE supplementation prevented significant reductions in gynoid fat, bone mineral content, and bone mineral density observed in the placebo group, suggesting potential benefits for metabolic and bone health in metabolic syndrome patients.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥40 years with metabolic syndrome (mean age 61.6 years, 77% female, 23% male).
effective_dosage: 4 g daily (2 g BID with food).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the potential positive relationships between erythrocyte LCPUFA-ω3 (including EPA) and hyperandrogenemia in adolescent girls with obesity.
results_summary: The study found that higher erythrocyte EPA levels were associated with a reduced risk of hyperandrogenemia. In the longitudinal analysis, EPA supplementation increased EPA levels and SHBG while decreasing free testosterone, suggesting a preventive role against hyperandrogenemia.
population_specificity: Adolescent girls with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between dose-specific omega-3 supplementation (including eicosapentaenoic acid) and cardiovascular disease outcomes.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplementation at ≤1 capsule/day showed no association with CVD outcomes, while 2 capsules/day demonstrated a statistically significant reduction in cardiac death. Higher doses (2-4 capsules/day) showed potential benefits but require further evaluation.
population_specificity: Adults in randomized clinical trials (n=83,617) focused on cardiovascular disease prevention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of EPA, DHA, and/or ALA supplementation during pregnancy on the prevention of pregnancy-induced hypertension or preeclampsia.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that n-3 fatty acids (including EPA) supplementation reduced the risk of preeclampsia but did not mitigate the risk of pregnancy-induced hypertension. The effect on preeclampsia was statistically significant with low heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, particularly those with low-risk pregnancies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether EPA supplementation reduces muscle inflammation and preserves physical function in patients undergoing colorectal cancer resection.
results_summary: EPA supplementation showed no significant differences in muscle NFĸB expression, lean muscle mass, aerobic capacity, or hand-grip strength compared to placebo after surgery. The study concluded that EPA provided no measurable benefits in inflammatory status or physical function post-surgery.
population_specificity: 61 patients (68.3 ± 0.95 years; 42 male) scheduled for colorectal cancer resection.
study_duration: 5 days before and 21 days after surgery (26 days total)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ethyl eicosapentaenoic acid in reducing atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk in high-risk patients with elevated triglycerides and well-controlled LDL-C.
results_summary: The REDUCE-IT trial demonstrated that 4 g daily of icosapent ethyl significantly reduced ASCVD events, including cardiovascular death, in high-risk patients with elevated triglycerides. This effect was observed across primary and secondary endpoints, surpassing statin therapy alone.
population_specificity: High-risk ASCVD patients with elevated baseline triglycerides (median 216.0 mg/dL) and well-controlled LDL-C (median 75.0 mg/dL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an EPA-enriched supplement versus a conventional supplement on body weight and composition in malnourished head and neck cancer patients during the perioperative period.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in body weight, composition, hospitalization days, or postoperative complications between the EPA-enriched and standard supplement groups. EPA additives did not influence perioperative weight changes in these patients.
population_specificity: Malnourished patients with head and neck cancer undergoing surgery.
study_duration: 7 days preoperative through 14 days postoperative (total 21 days)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) in managing major depression and explore its brain metabolism mechanisms.
results_summary: Meta-analyses suggest EPA supplementation may help manage major depression symptoms. Recent studies show EPA enters the brain but is rapidly metabolized, potentially influencing cell signaling via phospholipid esterification. Peripheral EPA-derived signaling molecules may also affect brain function.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of multiple studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether EPA-enriched nutrition support during neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (NACRT) for pancreatic cancer could improve nutritional status and reduce treatment-related toxicities.
results_summary: EPA-enriched intake showed potential to improve skeletal muscle mass and psoas major muscle area in patients who consumed ≥50% of the supplement, but no significant differences were found in other nutritional parameters or toxicity. Many patients struggled to consume the supplement due to its disagreeable taste.
population_specificity: Patients with pancreatic cancer receiving neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (NACRT).
effective_dosage: 2 bottles/day (550 kcal/day) of an EPA-enriched nutrition supplement.
study_duration: Duration of NACRT (specific length not stated in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of high-dose eicosapentaenoic ethyl ester in reducing cardiovascular events in high-risk patients with hypertriglyceridaemia/low HDL-C.
results_summary: High-dose eicosapentaenoic ethyl ester significantly reduced first and recurrent cardiovascular events in high-risk patients with hypertriglyceridaemia/low HDL-C, despite omega-3 fatty acids generally not being effective in secondary prevention.
population_specificity: High-risk patients with hypertriglyceridaemia and low HDL-C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of omega-3 PUFAs, including eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), in reducing systemic oxidative stress and improving NAFLD/NASH features in adults.
results_summary: The study found that n-3 PUFA supplementation may be effective in early stages of NAFLD but not in severe NAFLD or NASH, while its impact on oxidative stress remains controversial.
population_specificity: Adults with NAFLD or NASH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Eicosapentaenoic Acid (EPA) in reducing cardiovascular events in high-risk patients with elevated triglyceride levels despite statin use.
results_summary: The study found that daily administration of 4 g of icosapent ethyl significantly reduced the risk of ischemic events, including cardiovascular death, in high-risk patients with elevated triglycerides. Previous trials with n-3 fatty acids had neutral outcomes, but this trial demonstrated clinically meaningful benefits.
population_specificity: High-risk patients with elevated triglyceride levels (>2.3 mmol/L or 200 mg/dL) despite statin use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of omega-3 supplementation, including eicosapentaenoic acid, in reducing ADHD symptoms in children and adolescents.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant reduction in ADHD symptoms as measured by the Conners' rating scale, with both experiment and control groups showing similar reductions. There was little supportive evidence to validate omega-3 supplementation for ADHD symptom reduction.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with ADHD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether increased estradiol (E2) levels and omega-3 PUFA supplementation (specifically EPA) during pregnancy were associated with reduced depressive symptoms and changes in inflammatory cytokines.
results_summary: The study found that increased EPA and E2 levels were significantly associated with reduced depressive symptoms in pregnant women receiving omega-3 supplementation, but not in the placebo group. No association was found between EPA, E2, and changes in inflammatory cytokines.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with depressive symptoms (Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale scores ≥9) at 12-24 weeks of gestation.
effective_dosage: 1800 mg omega-3 fatty acids (containing 1206 mg EPA) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the nutritional and therapeutic benefits of Eicosapentaenoic Acid (EPA) and explore sustainable production methods using oleaginous micro-organisms.
results_summary: The study highlights EPA's significant role in preventing and treating cardiovascular and neurological disorders, its anti-inflammatory properties, and joint support benefits. It also identifies drawbacks of fish oil-derived EPA and proposes microbial production as a sustainable alternative.
population_specificity: General human health (not specific to a particular demographic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) supplementation prevents depletion of lean body mass and muscle mass in hospitalized patients with exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: EPA supplementation did not significantly preserve lean body mass or muscle mass compared to the control group during short-term hospitalization, though plasma EPA levels increased in the treatment group. The study suggested that longer-term EPA supplementation might be more effective for muscle recovery post-exacerbation.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with exacerbation of COPD.
effective_dosage: 1 g/day of EPA-enriched oral nutrition supplementation.
study_duration: Duration of hospitalization (specific length not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and tolerability of omega-3 PUFA supplementation, specifically Eicosapentaenoic Acid, for treating trait anxiety in adolescent females with restrictive anorexia nervosa.
results_summary: Omega-3 PUFA supplementation was well tolerated, with no significant differences in side effects between groups. However, there was no evidence that omega-3 PUFA provided additional anxiety benefits beyond nutritional restoration, as both groups showed similar reductions in anxiety scores.
population_specificity: Adolescent females with restrictive anorexia nervosa in a Partial Hospitalization Program.
effective_dosage: 2,120 mg eicosapentaenoic acid and 600 mg docosahexaenoic acid daily.

study_goal: To determine if preoperative EPA-enriched enteral diets could reduce hypercytokinemia and infectious complications after pancreatoduodenectomy.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in IL-6 levels or infectious complication rates between the EPA-supplemented and control groups, suggesting no marked impact of preoperative immunonutrition.
population_specificity: Patients with resectable periampullary cancer undergoing pancreatoduodenectomy.
effective_dosage: 600 kcal/day containing EPA (exact EPA amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether high-dose omega-3 fatty acid supplementation, including eicosapentaenoic acid, reduces cigarette craving and oxidative stress in heavy-smoker males.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 supplementation significantly reduced nicotine dependence, cigarette craving, and daily cigarette consumption compared to placebo. It also significantly decreased oxidative stress markers (total oxidant status and oxidative stress index).
population_specificity: Heavy-smoker males (smoking ≥20 cigarettes per day)
effective_dosage: Five 1g capsules daily (each containing 180mg eicosapentaenoic acid and 120mg docosahexaenoic acid)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of EPA supplementation on sulfhydryl amino acids (Met, Cys) and Atherogenic Index of Plasma (AIP) in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: EPA supplementation significantly reduced Met and Cys levels and improved AIP compared to placebo, suggesting potential benefits in preventing vascular complications in T2DM patients.
population_specificity: 36 control and patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of EPA supplementation on plasma FGF21 levels and fatty acid profiles in overweight/obese women following hypocaloric diets.
results_summary: EPA supplementation increased FGF21 levels, decreased n-6-PUFAs, and increased n-3-PUFAs (mainly EPA and DPA), while also affecting desaturase activity. These changes were associated with alterations in FGF21 levels.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate metabolomic changes following dietary supplementation of EPA alone or combined with α-LA in healthy overweight/obese sedentary women on an energy-restricted diet.
results_summary: The study identified metabolomic changes associated with α-LA supplementation, including an ascorbate intermediate metabolite linked to antioxidant effects. EPA's effects were less highlighted, but correlations suggested potential benefits in reducing cardiovascular risk factors.
population_specificity: Healthy overweight/obese sedentary women
effective_dosage: EPA (1.3 g/d), α-LA (0.3 g/d), or combined (1.3 g/d EPA + 0.3 g/d α-LA)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of fatty acids, particularly eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), in the pathophysiology of psychiatric disorders and assess its potential as a disease-modifying nutraceutical.
results_summary: The study found that EPA supplementation shows clinical potential, especially as an add-on therapy in depressed patients with increased inflammation markers. Fatty acid alterations are linked to various pathophysiological mechanisms, suggesting EPA may help optimize treatment for psychiatric disorders.
population_specificity: Patients with major depressive disorder (MDD), posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and schizophrenia, particularly those with increased inflammation markers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an EPA-enriched nutritional supplement could prevent weight loss and reduce inflammatory markers in head and neck carcinoma patients during the perioperative period.
results_summary: The supplement significantly increased EPA levels but did not prevent further weight loss or alter inflammatory markers in cachectic patients. No difference in postoperative complications was observed between groups.
population_specificity: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma patients with ≥5% weight loss undergoing major surgery with free flap reconstruction.
effective_dosage: Two packs of Prosure® per day (exact EPA content not specified).
study_duration: 28 days (from 2 weeks before to 2 weeks after surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary arachidonic acid (ARA) supplementation affects skeletal muscle phospholipid incorporation and inflammatory/adaptive processes in resistance-trained men.
results_summary: ARA supplementation altered plasma and muscle fatty acid profiles, reduced circulating immune cell markers, and increased myogenic gene expression without increasing systemic or intramuscular inflammation.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained men (≥1 year of training) aged 24 ± 1.5 years (ARA group) and 26 ± 1.3 years (placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of EPA and DHA-enriched fish oil on nutritional and immunological parameters in treatment-naïve breast cancer patients.
results_summary: Supplementation significantly increased plasma phospholipid EPA and DHA levels and maintained CD4+ T-cell levels, but no anthropometric differences were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Treatment-naïve breast cancer patients.
effective_dosage: 2 g/day of fish oil concentrate containing 1.8 g of n-3 fatty acids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 fatty acid supplements, including eicosapentaenoic acid, reduce the risk of fatal and nonfatal coronary heart disease and major vascular events in high-risk individuals.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant associations between omega-3 fatty acid supplementation and reduced risk of coronary heart disease death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, or major vascular events, either overall or in any prespecified subgroups. The study does not support current recommendations for omega-3 supplementation in people with a history of coronary heart disease.
population_specificity: High-risk individuals (77,917 participants, 61.4% men, mean age 64.0 years) with prior coronary heart disease, diabetes, elevated lipid levels, or statin use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 supplementation, specifically eicosapentaenoic acid, could reduce inflammation in HIV and HHV-8 coinfected adults, with a focus on Kaposi sarcoma patients.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplementation decreased IL-6 concentrations in HIV and HHV-8 coinfected participants, with a trend toward reduced IL-6 in Kaposi sarcoma patients. CD8 T-cell counts also showed a tendency to increase in the omega-3 arm among Kaposi sarcoma patients.
population_specificity: HIV and HHV-8 coinfected Ugandan adults, including 56 Kaposi sarcoma patients and 11 Kaposi sarcoma-negative participants.
effective_dosage: 1.8-g eicosapentaenoic acid and 1.2-mg docosapentaenoic acid daily (3-g total pill dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of MAG-EPA supplementation on prostate cancer proliferation, inflammation mediators, and quality of life in men undergoing radical prostatectomy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as it describes a proposed study design rather than reporting outcomes.
population_specificity: 130 men with prostate cancer (Gleason score ≥7) scheduled for radical prostatectomy.
effective_dosage: 6 capsules of 625 mg fish oil (MAG-EPA) per capsule (500 mg EPA daily).
study_duration: 4 to 10 weeks prior to surgery and continued for one year post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers examined whether urinary oxylipins derived from eicosapentaenoic acid (among other fatty acids) were altered during prolonged training and polyphenol-rich beverage intake in elite triathletes.
results_summary: Physical activity reduced the excretion of certain oxylipin metabolites from eicosapentaenoic acid, suggesting an impact on its metabolic pathways. The polyphenol-rich beverage (ACJ) also reduced the excretion of a specific prostaglandin metabolite.
population_specificity: 16 elite triathletes
effective_dosage: Not specified for eicosapentaenoic acid (beverage: 200 mL/day of ACJ)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of EPA supplementation on serum levels and activity of PON1 in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: EPA supplementation significantly increased serum levels and activity of PON1, improved the PON1/HDL-c ratio, and led to favorable changes in lipid profiles, FBS, and HbA1c. No significant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients (n=36)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of EPA-enriched nutritional supplementation on inflammatory markers in patients with oral cavity cancer.
results_summary: The study found lower CRP and CRP/albumin ratio in the EPA group compared to controls, but no significant differences between groups post-intervention. Correlations between inflammatory markers and albumin were observed in both groups.
population_specificity: 53 patients with oral cavity cancer in antineoplastic pretreatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the dietary intake and blood concentrations of essential fatty acids, including eicosapentaenoic acid, in patients with PKU on long-term dietary treatment.
results_summary: Erythrocyte eicosapentaenoic acid levels were below reference values in 6% of patients, indicating potential deficiency despite adequate total fat intake. The study did not report significant adverse effects or benefits related to eicosapentaenoic acid.
population_specificity: Dutch patients with phenylketonuria (PKU), aged 1-39 years, on long-term dietary treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA)-enriched nutrition could reduce bodyweight loss in patients undergoing total gastrectomy for gastric cancer compared to a standard diet.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in bodyweight loss at 1 or 3 months post-surgery between patients receiving EPA supplementation and those on a standard diet. Surgical morbidity rates were similar between groups, indicating no added benefit from EPA in this context.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total gastrectomy for gastric cancer.
effective_dosage: 2.2 g EPA daily (as part of a 600 kcal supplement, ProSure®).
study_duration: 7 days before and 21 days after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether EPA + DHA supplementation could reduce muscle damage and inflammation following eccentric exercise.
results_summary: EPA + DHA supplementation improved muscle strength recovery (MVC) and range of motion (ROM) post-exercise, reduced muscle soreness, and moderated IL-6 levels compared to placebo. The effects were statistically significant but limited in scope.
population_specificity: 24 healthy men
effective_dosage: 600 mg EPA + 260 mg DHA per day
study_duration: 8 weeks before exercise, continued until 5 days post-exercise

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of fish oil supplementation (containing EPA) during pregnancy on maternal serum fatty acid profiles.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation significantly increased serum DHA levels but did not significantly increase EPA levels compared to placebo. The study concluded that 1,000 mg/day fish oil supplementation during pregnancy may improve serum fatty acid composition.
population_specificity: 150 pregnant women aged 18-35 years in Tabriz, Iran.
effective_dosage: 1,000 mg fish oil daily (containing 180 mg EPA and 120 mg DHA).
study_duration: From week 21 of pregnancy to delivery.

study_goal: To assess the effectiveness and tolerability of omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (EPA and DHA) in controlling seizures in people with refractory epilepsy.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent results, with significant seizure reduction observed in one high-risk-of-bias study involving children but no significant effects in adults. No major adverse effects were reported, but potential bleeding risks were not assessed.
population_specificity: Adults and children with refractory epilepsy (155 total participants: 85 adults, 70 children).
effective_dosage: 2.2 g/day (EPA:DHA 3:2 ratio), 1.7 g/day (1g EPA + 0.7g DHA), and 3 ml/day fish oil (0.24g DHA + 0.36g EPA).

study_goal: The researchers compared the nutritional status, including Eicosapentaenoic Acid (EPA) levels, between long-term vegans and non-vegetarians.
results_summary: Vegans showed higher proportions of Eicosapentaenoic Acid than expected, indicating favorable fatty acid profiles despite lower intake of key nutrients.
population_specificity: Finnish long-term vegans (n = 22) and sex- and age-matched non-vegetarians (n = 19).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of immunonutrition (including EPA) on postoperative complications and the role of resolvin E1 in reducing inflammation in patients undergoing major hepatobiliary resection.
results_summary: Preoperative immunonutrition with EPA reduced infectious complications and inflammatory responses, with higher resolvin E1 and lower interleukin-6 levels post-operation. Resolvin E1 appeared to mediate the anti-inflammatory effects of EPA supplementation.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing major hepatobiliary resection (n=40).
effective_dosage: Not specified (oral supplementation enriched with EPA, arginine, and nucleotides).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify ongoing RCTs investigating the effects of eicosapentaenoic acid in colorectal adenoma survivors.
results_summary: The abstract mentions an ongoing RCT investigating eicosapentaenoic acid in colorectal adenoma survivors, but no results or conclusions are provided.
population_specificity: Colorectal adenoma survivors
